results.title: When ‘Saturday Night Live’ Debuted, They Were There. Here’s What They Remember.
results.abstract: With a new film about the show, and a 50th anniversary season starting, Chevy Chase, Garrett Morris, Jane Curtin, Laraine Newman and others look back.

results.title: New York Film Festival Pitches Its Ever-Expanding, Global Tent
results.abstract: Standout selections include “Nickel Boys,” the Mumbai-set “All We Imagine as Light” and the documentary “Dahomey,” about African repatriation.

results.title: Maggie Smith: A Life in Pictures
results.abstract: She had a long, award-winning career as a screen and stage actress, finally becoming a household name with her memorable turn in “Downton Abbey.”

results.title: 10 Great Maggie Smith Performances to Stream
results.abstract: In “Downton Abbey,” “A Room With a View” and dozens of other films and television series, she delighted audiences with her portrayal of sharp, tart-tongued and often wryly funny Englishwomen.
des_facet: The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Maggie Smith as Violet Crawley, the dowager countess, in “Downton Abbey.” She made the character more than just a collection of gripes, finding the humanity in a woman as she watches the rapid decline of a world she once ruled.

results.title: Katy Perry’s Latest Album Isn’t as Bad as Her Timing
results.abstract: The pop singer’s latest LP, “143,” has been gleefully panned, but its musical faults aren’t as remarkable as Perry’s failure to read the current cultural moment.

multimedia.caption: Katy Perry’s “143” comes at a time when the promotion and rollout strategies for albums are often scrutinized as heavily as their content.
Katy Perry’s “143” comes at a time when the promotion and rollout strategies for albums are often scrutinized as heavily as their content.

results.title: Chappell Roan Cancels a Pair of Big Shows After Tumultuous Weeks
results.abstract: The pop star said things had “gotten overwhelming” and bowed out of festivals in New York and Maryland after a period in which her politics came under scrutiny.

results.title: National Symphony Orchestra Players Go on Strike, Canceling Gala
results.abstract: The Washington-based group’s first work stoppage in 46 years came after management and musicians failed to reach a salary agreement.
org_facet: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

multimedia.caption: The National Symphony Orchestra, seen at the Kennedy Center in February, rejected a proposed 13 percent raise over four years. The musicians have asked for a raise of about 25 percent.
multimedia.copyright: Craig Hudson for The Washington Post, via Getty Images

results.title: With Sean Combs in Jail, Civil Suits Continue to Pile Up
results.abstract: The latest lawsuit includes accusations of drugging and coerced sex as recently as this year. Mr. Combs’s lawyers have said the claims are attempts to obtain quick settlements.

multimedia.caption: In the past year, eight women have accused Sean Combs of sexual assault in lawsuits.
In the past year, eight women have accused Sean Combs of sexual assault in lawsuits.

results.title: ‘Titaníque’ Was Her Big Hit. Is ‘Big Gay Jamboree’ Really Her Swan Song?
results.abstract: Two years after debuting the “Titanic” parody, Marla Mindelle says her new show, with Margot Robbie as a producer, may be her last as an actor.

multimedia.caption: “It is the amalgamation of someone who loves musical theater so much, but has been trolled by musical theater her entire life, which I feel is my journey,” Marla Mindelle said of her new show.
multimedia.copyright: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times

results.title: Van Gogh ‘Sunflowers’ Targeted Again as Protesters Are Sentenced to Jail
results.abstract: A judge said he hoped to deter protests when he handed down lengthy terms for the two activists, who dumped soup on the painting in 2022. Later that day, activists did it again.

results.title: Rubin Museum’s Tibetan Shrine Will Move to Brooklyn Museum
results.abstract: The collection of art and ritual objects will move to the Brooklyn Museum for six years starting in June after the Rubin closes its building to focus on traveling exhibitions and long-term loans.

multimedia.caption: The Tibetan Buddhist Shrine Room has been one of the most popular installations at the Rubin Museum of Art. The Rubin, which is closing its building, is loaning the shrine to the Brooklyn Museum for six years.
multimedia.copyright: via the Rubin Museum of Art; Photo by Dave De Armas

results.title: Lady Gaga’s ‘Joker,’ and a Tour of Musical Clowning
results.abstract: Clowns, harlequins, jokers and Pierrots have served as the main characters in countless songs over the years, but they’re rarely there to conjure cheap laughs.

results.title: Richard Pettibone, Master of the Artistic Miniature, Dies at 86
results.abstract: He painted tiny reproductions of works by Warhol, Lichtenstein, Duchamp and many others, raising questions about originality and creativity.

multimedia.caption: The artist Richard Pettibone in his studio in 2021. A prankish virtuoso of appropriation art, he created miniature copies of works by modern and contemporary masters.

results.title: Neil King Jr., Who Wrote of a Long Walk of ‘Renewal,’ Dies at 65
results.abstract: His book, “American Ramble,” lyrically recounted a 330-mile trek from Washington, D.C., to New York City while he was in remission from cancer.

results.title: Nick Gravenites, Mainstay of the San Francisco Rock Scene, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A blues devotee from Chicago, he tasted fame in the late 1960s with the Electric Flag, a band that made its debut at Monterey but proved short-lived.
